newsitem.title: UNITED NATIONS: UN Council to vote informally Tuesday on top post.
newsitem.headline: UN Council to vote informally Tuesday on top post.

text.p: The U.N. Security Council will hold its first informal poll on Tuesday in the contest for secretary-general, now that Boutros Boutros-Ghali has stepped aside in the race for the top U.N. post.
Council president Paolo Fulci said that the so-called straw poll would include the four candidates who had been nominated on Friday. No new names were added on Monday, he said.

The four nominated on Friday were: Kofi Annan of Ghana, the U.N. undersecretary-general for peacekeeping; Hamid Algabid of Niger, secretary-general of the Organisation of Islamic Conference; Amara Essy, foreign minister of the Ivory Coast; and Ahmedou Ould-Abdallah of Mauritania, the former U.N. special envoy for Burundi who is executive secretary of the Washington-based Global Coalition for Africa.
Salim A. Salim of Tanzania, the secretary-general of the Organisation of African Unity, who South African was expected to nominate on Monday, however, did not submit his name.
Any winning candidate has to get at least nine votes and no veto from one of the five permanent members -- the United States, Russia, China, Britain and France.

But in the confusing U.N. procedures, members can vote for more than one candidate and a veto does not necessarily preclude another vote -- and another veto -- on the same candidate. Any candidate approved by the council must be endorsed by the 185-member General Assembly.
